Imaging:
===============
___ CT Abdomen:
There is massive dilatation of the transverse colon measuring up 
to 13.7 cm. This is similar to slightly progressed when compared 
to the prior study.  The presence of air in the descending colon 
and rectum makes mechanical obstruction less likely.  There is 
bowel wall edema evident in the descending colon consistent with 
the findings on the prior CT.  There is loss of normal haustra 
pattern within the massively distended transverse colon.  Toxic 
megacolon cannot be excluded however the time course with 
stability over a 6 day period is not typical.  No free air seen.

___ CXR (TB screen):
The tip of the PICC projects over the distal SVC.  There is no 
focal
consolidation.  There is no pleural effusion.  The trachea is 
midline.  The aorta is atherosclerotic and tortuous.  
Degenerative changes are evident in the spine.

___ MRE enterography:
1. Active inflammation involving an approximately 8.0 cm segment 
of sigmoid colon, with wall thickening and pericolonic vascular 
prominence.
2. Subacute inflammation involving the rectum.  Please note that 
the anal canal was not included on this examination.
3. Ahaustral dilated transverse colon and ahaustral nondilated 
descending colon, suggesting chronic inflammation.  Focal 
narrowed caliber of the proximal transverse colon with the lumen 
measuring 1.3 cm, similar to prior CT.
4. No evidence of small bowel inflammation.
5. Fusiform 4.9 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm.

FINDINGS: 
CT ABDOMEN WITH CONTRAST:  The imaged lung bases demonstrate a 
small right pleural effusion and bibasilar atelectasis with 
emphysema. The heart and pericardium are unremarkable without 
effusion. The pulmonary emboli are better assessed on the CT 
Chest but basilar opacity could reflect atelectasis, however 
infarct cannot be excluded. 
  
The liver is normal in attenuation without focal lesion, intra 
or extrahepatic biliary ductal dilatation.  The gallbladder is 
decompressed.  The pancreas, spleen and right adrenal gland are 
unremarkable.  Nodularity is seen in the left adrenal gland of 
uncertain significance, measuring up to 16 mm (7:22) with a 
second nodule in the lateral limb of the left adrenal gland 
measuring 9 mm (7:24).  The kidneys enhance and excrete contrast 
symmetrically without hydronephrosis.   
  
The stomach, small and large bowel are unremarkable with 
equivocal 
hyperenhancement of the right lower quadrant small bowel loops 
and may be 
reactive to the free fluid.  The large bowel contains multiple 
diverticula, but none demonstrate active inflammatory changes.  
There is no free air in the abdomen.  The appendix is seen and 
is normal.  Mild stranding is seen in the mesentery likely 
communicating with a moderate volume of free fluid within the 
pelvis.  There is no pathologic mesenteric or retroperitoneal 
lymph node enlargement.  The aorta and major branches appear 
patent and normal in caliber with minimal vascular 
calcifications. 
  
CT PELVIS WITH CONTRAST:  The bladder is decompressed with a 
thickened wall and Foley catheter within. The degree of bladder 
wall thickening is greater than just due to decompression alone. 
Multiple bladder diverticula are identified (7:69), 2 of which 
appear to contain stones.  A small to moderate volume of free 
fluid is seen in the pelvis.  There is no pelvic or inguinal 
lymph node enlargement. The prostate is mildly enlarged. 
OSSEOUS STRUCTURES:  There is no suspicious lytic or blastic 
bony lesion to suggest osseous malignancy.   
IMPRESSION: 
1.  Right lower quadrant free fluid could be reactive to bladder 
wall 
thickening; correlate with urinalysis to exclude infectious 
causes. Right 
lower quadrant small bowel loops appear mildly hyperenhancing 
which could 
reflect enteritis or reactive changes.  
2.  Diverticulosis without diverticulitis.  Normal appendix.    
3. Multiple bladder diverticula which contain small bladder 
stones.

ERCP: The scout film was normal. During biliary cannulation, the 
pancreatic duct was partially filled with contrast and 
visualized proximally. The course and caliber of the duct was 
normal with no evidence of filling defects, masses, chronic 
pancreatitis or other abnormalities. The bile duct was deeply 
cannulated with the sphincterotome. Contrast was injected and 
there was brisk flow through the ducts. Contrast extended to the 
entire biliary tree. The CBD was 8mm in diameter. One filling 
defect consistent with a stone was identified in the distal CBD. 
Opacification of the gallbladder was incomplete. The left and 
right hepatic ducts and all intrahepatic branches were normal. 
A biliary sphincterotomy was made with a sphincterotome. There 
was no post-sphincterotomy bleeding. The biliary tree was swept 
with a balloon starting at the bifurcation. One stone was 
removed. The CBD and CHD were swept repeatedly until no further 
stones were seen. Excellent bile and contrast drainage was seen 
endoscopically and fluoroscopically. Overall, successful ERCP 
with sphincterotomy and stone extraction. Medications On Admission: The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.

severe
depression over the past two weeks with frequent thoughts of SI. 

He reports prominent hopelessness, low energy, sleep
interruptions, poor motivation and decreased interest.  He 
denies

"wants to get help before I get that bad again."  

Patient reports that his depression became notably worse in the
context of his brother becoming acutely ill approximately 6
months ago.  During this time, he was regularly caring for his
brother, who was on the waiting list for an organ transplant;
however, he passed away 2 months ago before he was able to
receive one.  Since his brother's passing, he reports that his
nieces and nephews have been taking advantage of him.  

Patient reports that approximately one month ago, he "checked
myself into ___" for similar symptoms of depression, 
along
with suicidal ideation and plan to kill himself by "strapping
weights to my body and drowning myself."  He found the
hospitalization helpful, but did not follow-up with aftercare 
and
stopped taking his psychiatric medications once he ran out.

grinded his thumb into a block of wood.  He reflects that he had
hoped the physical pain would improve his emotional pain, but 
now

Conclusions   
The left atrium and right atrium are normal in cavity size. The 
estimated right atrial pressure is ___ mmHg. Left ventricular 
wall thickness, cavity size, and global systolic function are 
normal (LVEF>55%). Due to suboptimal technical quality, a focal 
wall motion abnormality cannot be fully excluded. Right 
ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. There 
is abnormal septal motion/position. The diameters of aorta at 
the sinus, ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic 
valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened. There is no aortic 
valve stenosis. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. 
The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal. 
There is an anterior space which most likely represents a 
prominent fat pad, although a pericardial effusion cannot be 
excluded with this suboptimal study. No diastolic RV collapse to 
suggest tamponade. Medications On Admission: The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.

preserved regional and low normal global left ventricular 
systolic function. Moderate pulmonary artery systolic 
hypertension. Mild-moderate mitral regurgitation. Mildly dilated 
thoracic aorta. Increased PCWP. Absent transmitral A wave.

and absent transmitral A wave and multivalvular regurgitation 
are suggestive of an infiltrative process (e.g., amyloid).

and

generalized

are

repeated mouth

with

FINDINGS:

enhances 
homogenously without focal lesions.  Gallbladder, spleen, 
pancreas, and 
adrenal glands are within normal limits.  Kidneys enhance 
symmetrically 
without focal lesion or hydronephrosis. 
Stomach is distended with oral contrast but does not show wall 
thickening.  The duodenal sweep is unremarkable.  Proximal loops 
of small bowel are distended with oral contrast but do not show 
wall thickening or signs of obstruction.  Distal small bowel 
loops are less distended.  Prominent enhancement of the colon, 
ascending colon in particular, may relate to the phase of 
contrast; however, there is also mild thickening of the colonic 
wall and minimal fat stranding which could reflect colitis. The 
appendix is normal. 
There is no mesenteric or retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy.  
There is no 
intra-abdominal free fluid or free air. 
Bladder, seminal vesicles, and prostate are unremarkable.  There 
is no pelvic free fluid.  There is no inguinal or pelvic 
lymphadenopathy. 
Osseous structures are unremarkable. 
IMPRESSION:   
Mucosal hyperenhancement in the ascending colon with mild wall 
thickening and minimal stranding may represent mild colitis.

normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. The left ventricular 
inflow pattern suggests impaired relaxation. There is borderline 
pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial 
effusion.

secondary to SBP. Initially this was responsive to albumin, but 
subsequently worsened with concern for development of 
hepatorenal syndrome. She became anuric and volume overloaded 
with worsening lower extremity edema, ascites, and pulmonary 
edema. She was transferred to MICU.

#Respiratory failure: Patient had some shortness of breath on 
admission which was improved substantially with nebulizer 
treatments. After receiving FFP and platelets prior to a 
paracentesis, her shortness of breath worsened with crackles on 
exam. This progress as renal function worsened with icnreased 
work of breathing, and new O2 requirement. TTE was done which 
did not show any diastolic/systolic dysfunction.

#Anemia: Patient presented with anemia and concern for 
hemolysis/DIC versus bleeding into a known rectus sheath 
hematoma at outside hospital. Labs were concerning for DIC with 
low haptoglobin and fibrinogen; however these values were felt 
more likely to be explained by her underlying liver disease. 
Rectus sheath hematoma was followed on imaging and did not show 
expansion. Her hemoglobin subsequently stabilized.

#Hyperkalemia: Patient presented with hyperkalemia to 6.2 at 
outside hospital, as well as in house. ECG was followed and did 
not show changes. She was treated with kayexelate wtih good 
improvement. 

#Adrenal insufficiency: Because patient had hyperkalemia and 
hyponatremia, there was concern for adrenal insufficiency. ___ 
stim test revealed inadequate response. Endocrinology were 
consulted and recommended further workup given concern that 
patient's liver disease may lead to erroneous ___ stim test 
because of impaired synthesis of cortisol binding globulin. As 
patient's clinical status worsened, however, this was not 
performed.

#T2DM: Uncontrolled, A1c 9.0. She was continued on long acting 
and sliding scale insulin in house.

#Hyponatremia: Thought likely secondary to liver failure and 
acute renal failure with prerenal presentation. Sodium level was 
followed.

MICU COURSE
=============
___ yo woman with NASH cirrhosis (Class C, c/b ascites, SBP, no 
known varices), DM2, who presents as transfer from OSH with 
decompensated cirrhosis c/b SBP, bacteremia, and anemia, 
transferred to ___ for liver transplant evaluation and 
subsequently to the MICU for respiratory distress due to altered 
mental status and potential dialysis 

#RESPIRATORY COMRPOMISE: Ms. ___ presented with acute 
respiratory compromise in the setting of worsening obtundation. 
Her tachypnea was likely multifactorial secondary to 
hypervolemia in setting of anuria and worsening abdominal 
distension with ascites that may be compressing the diaphragm. 
Her recent pulmonary edema, potentially secondary to TRALI, is 
likely also contributing. Given this presentation in combination 
with her obtundation patient was intubated for airway 
protection. The patient continued to be intubated throughout her 
MICU course. 

#CIRRHOSIS C/B ASCITES, SBP and ABDOMINAL DISTENSION: Ms. 
___ presented with known cirrhosis complicated by SBP early 
in her course s/p 14-days of CTX as well as ciprofloxacin PPX 
that was initiated on ___ after arrival to ___. Recently 
she had worsening abdominal distension that may be secondary to 
a gastric outlet obstruction that is either functional or less 
likely, anatomic. Patient was started on meropenem given 
potential SBP. The patient continued to worsen during her MICU 
stay with increasing lactate levels, hypotension, and continued 
altered mental status. After discussions with the physicians 
given the patient's poor prognosis, the family of the patient 
including her health care proxy chose ___ measures only. All 
non-essential medications were discontinued including 
antibiotics. The patient continued to deteriorate with worsening 
lactate, anuria, and hypotension. The patient passed away due to 
the complications of her liver disease. 

#ACUTE ON CHRONIC RENAL FAILURE: Patient without very clear 
evidence of worsening creatinine however became anuric with 
increasing creatinine. Patient was in renal failure and in need 
of dialysis. The plan was to initiate hemodialysis but given the 
poor prognosis the patient's family switched goals of care to 
comfort measures only. 

#Ileus - patient continued to be without bowel movements over 
the course of her MICU stay. The OG tube was suctioned daily 
with eventually feculent material being extracted. A CT abdomen 
showed colonic ileus related to
ischemic changes vs. Oglivies which could have been contributing 
to her clinical status and worsening lactate. Given the poor 
prognosis no intervention was pursued.  

#COAGULOPATHY W/ CONCERN FOR ACTIVE BLEEDING: The patient had 
bright red blood at her posterior pharynx noticed during 
intubation. ENT was consulted and packed the nasopharyngeal 
pharynx with gauze with resolution of the bleed. The patient's 
INR continued to increase during her ICU stay. 

#ALTERED MENTAL STATUS: Ms. ___ presented with obtundation 
that is likely multifactorial secondary to hepatic 
encephalopathy and progressive renal failure. Prior to passing 
the patient experienced ventricular tachycardia with subsequent 
bradycardia and decreased blood pressures. Morphine was 
administered to comfort the patient during her final hours.

started
in a short position. The papilla was difficult to localise.
Multiple unsuccessfull attempts were made to cannulate with the
sphincterotome followed by the ___ cannula. At this point, it
was decided to switch to the linear EUS.   
EUS was performed using a linear echoendoscope at ___ MHz
frequency. The head and uncinate pancreas were imaged from the
duodenal bulb and the second / third duodenum. The ill defined
previously described mass was briefly seen. As we advanced the
scope in the D2 position, the major papilla with oozing bile was
clearly identified. 
It was decided to switch back to an ERCP scope. The major
papilla was seen in a distal position in D2, on the lateral rim
of a large ___ diverticulum. The procedure was done 
in
a long position. 
The bile duct was successfully cannulated using a Rx
sphincterotome preloaded with a 0.035in guidewire. Contrast was
injected and there was brisk flow through the ducts. 
Contrast injection showed a single 2 cm long tight stricture at
the level of the middle third CBD. There was significant
post-obstructive dilation of the CBD. The CHD, right and left
main hepatic ducts were not injected. Complete opacification was
not possible because of a very unstable scope position. The CBD
measured up to 12 mm in diameter. 
A biliary sphincterotomy was successfully performed with the
sphincterotome. There was no post-sphincterotomy bleeding. 
A cytology brush was then inserted to obtain specimen from the
mid third CBD stricture which was sent for cytology. 
Subsequently, a ___ x 9cm biliary strait plastic stent (Cotton
___ was successfully placed in the CBD using a preloaded 
OASIS
stent introducer kit. 
Excellent bile and contrast drainage was seen endoscopically and
fluoroscopically.

aorta is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are 
mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. No aortic 
regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are 
structurally normal. No mitral regurgitation is seen. The left 
ventricular inflow pattern suggests impaired relaxation. The 
pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be determined. 
There is no pericardial effusion. 
IMPRESSION: Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with 
preserved global and regional biventricular systolic function. 
Diastolic dysfunction. Mild aortic dilation.  

MRI/MRA/MRV (___): IMPRESSION: 
1. No evidence of a mass associated with the right parietal 
lobar hematoma. No evidence of additional hemorrhages to suggest 
amyloid angiopathy. Given the presence of blood products of 
varying chronicity, an underlying cavernoma may be present. 
Since this lesion is not included in the field of view of the 
current MRA, a repeated MRA or CTA should be considered to 
exclude an arteriovenous malformation. If no other source of 
hemorrhage is identified, then a follow-up MRI with contrast 
should be obtained after the resolution of acute/subacute blood 
products.  
2. Diffuse pachymeningeal enhancement, which may be related to 
carcinomatous meningitis, dural lymphoma, infectious 
(tuberculosis, fungal disease, Lyme disease, syphilis, etc.) or 
inflammatory etiologies (sarcoidosis, Wegener's granulomatosis, 
etc.). 
3. No evidence of active venous sinus thrombosis. Focal 
fenestration in the posterior aspect of the superior sagittal 
sinus, which may represent anatomic variation or recanalization 
following a previous thrombosis.

1. Unchanged appearance of right parietal intraparenchymal

___ of 9 mm, is seen in the left quadrigeminal plate

or other 
vascular abnormality.

Conclusions :The left atrium and right atrium are normal in

MRI OF THE BRAIN WITH AND WITHOUT CONTRAST 
  
CLINICAL INDICATION: ___ woman with new diagnosis of 
lymphoma, 
admitted with falls and to have a possible brain metastases, 
evaluate for 
lymphoma and leptomeningeal disease. 
  
COMPARISON: Prior head CT dated ___. 
  
TECHNIQUE: Pre-contrast axial and sagittal images were obtained, 
axial FLAIR, axial T2, axial magnetic susceptibility and axial 
diffusion-weighted sequences. The T1-weighted images were 
repeated after the administration of gadolinium contrast in 
axial T1, sagittal MP-RAGE and also multiplanar reconstructions 
were provided. 
  
FINDINGS: On the left frontal subcortical white matter, there is 
an enhancing mass lesion, measuring approximately 21 x 20 mm in 
transverse dimension by  21.5 x 2.0 mm in sagittal projection, 
this lesion demonstrates significant vasogenic edema and mild 
effacement of the sulci at the convexity with minimal shifting 
of the frontal lobe towards the right, there is no evidence of 
hydrocephalus. The T2 and FLAIR sequences, demonstrates multiple 
scattered foci of high signal intensity, distributed in the 
subcortical white matter, which are nonspecific and may reflect 
chronic microvascular ischemic disease.   
No other enhancing lesions are noted throughout the brain, there 
is no 
evidence of abnormal leptomeningeal enhancement to suggest 
meningeal 
infiltration. Normal flow void signal is noted at the major 
vascular 
structures. The diffusion-weighted sequences are normal with no 
evidence of acute or subacute ischemic changes. The mass lesion 
demonstrates moderate restricted diffusion. 
  
The orbits, the paranasal sinuses and the mastoid air cells are 
grossly 
unremarkable. 
  
IMPRESSION: Enhancing mass lesion identified at the subcortical 
white matter of the left frontal lobe as described in detail 
above, possibly representing a metastatic lesion versus a 
primary brain neoplasm, associated with vasogenic edema and 
effacement of the sulci.

CLINICAL INDICATION: ___ woman with newly diagnosed 
lymphoma, 
admitted with falls and found to have a possible brain 
metastases, evaluate for leptomeningeal spread or lymphoma. 
  
COMPARISON: Prior CT of the cervical spine dated ___. 
  
MRI OF THE CERVICAL SPINE: 
  
Sagittal T1, T2 and sagittal STIR sequences were obtained, axial 
T2 and 
gradient echo sequences. The T1-weighted images were repeated 
after the 
administration of gadolinium contrast material. 
  
FINDINGS: There is mild straightening and reversal of the normal 
cervical 
lordosis with degenerative anterolisthesis at C4 upon C5 level. 
The signal 
intensity in the spinal cord throughout the cervical spine is 
normal with no evidence of focal or diffuse lesions to indicate 
spinal cord edema or cord expansion. 
  
Multilevel degenerative changes are visualized throughout the 
cervical spine as follows: 
  
At C3/C4 level, bilateral uncovertebral hypertrophy is 
identified, causing 
mild bilateral neural foraminal narrowing, there is no 
significant spinal 
canal stenosis. 
  
C4/C5 demonstrates posterior central disc bulge and bilateral 
uncovertebral hypertrophy, causing anterior thecal sac deformity 
and mild bilateral neural foraminal narrowing. 
  
At C5/C6 level, bilateral uncovertebral hypertrophy is noted and 
also mild 
posterior disc bulge. 
  
C6/C7 level demonstrates posterior disc bulge and bilateral 
uncovertebral 
hypertrophy, left greater than right, causing left side neural 
foraminal 
narrowing (image 35, series 5014). 
  
The visualized paravertebral structures are normal, there is no 
evidence of abnormal enhancement. 
  
IMPRESSION: Multilevel degenerative changes throughout the 
cervical spine as described above, there is no evidence of 
abnormal enhancement or abnormal signal within the cervical 
spinal cord. 
  
MRI OF THE THORACIC SPINE. 
  
The alignment and configuration of the thoracic vertebral bodies 
is normal.  High signal intensity is noted throughout the 
vertebral bodies in the bone marrow, likely consistent with bone 
marrow replacement for fat. 
  
At T2/T3 level, minimal posterior central disc bulge is 
identified with no 
evidence of neural foraminal narrowing or spinal canal stenosis. 

  
From T3/T4 through T8/T9 levels, there are mild posterior disc 
bulges with no evidence of neural foraminal narrowing or 
significant spinal canal stenosis. 
  
Signal intensity throughout the thoracic spinal cord is normal 
and the conus medullaris terminates at the level of T12. There 
is no evidence of abnormal enhancement. 
  
IMPRESSION: Mild multilevel degenerative changes throughout the 
thoracic 
spine as described above, there is no evidence of abnormal 
enhancement. 
  
MRI OF THE LUMBAR SPINE: 
  
There is mild grade 1 anterolisthesis at L4 upon L5 level, 
apparently 
degenerative in nature. At L2/L3 level, there is disc 
desiccation and mild 
posterior disc bulge, causing mild bilateral neural foraminal 
narrowing, there is also mild articular joint facet hypertrophy 
(image 4, series 5002). 
  
At L3/L4 level, there is a prominent posterior disc bulge, 
asymmetric towards the right, causing significant neural 
foraminal narrowing and moderate spinal canal stenosis, there is 
also articular joint facet hypertrophy. The psoas muscle on the 
right, demonstrates a focal lesion, possibly consistent with a 
hematoma, calcification, formally a metastasis in this area 
cannot be completely excluded (image 9, 10, series 5002), this 
lesion measures approximately 19 x 23 mm in transverse 
dimension. 
  
L4-L5 level demonstrates disc degenerative changes with 
posterior broad-based disc bulge, causing anterior thecal sac 
deformity and bilateral neural foraminal narrowing, there is 
also moderate articular joint facet hypertrophy, resulting in 
moderate-to-severe spinal canal stenosis. 
  
L5-S1 level demonstrates posterior disc bulging, causing 
anterior thecal sac deformity and apparently contacting the 
traversing nerve roots bilaterally, there is also moderate 
articular joint facet hypertrophy resulting in moderate spinal 
canal stenosis. There is no evidence of abnormal enhancement to 
indicate leptomeningeal disease. 
  
IMPRESSION: Multilevel degenerative changes throughout the 
cervical, 
thoracic, and lumbar spine as described in detail above. There 
is a focal 
lesion within the right psoas at the level of L3/L4, possibly 
consistent with a hematoma, calcification, formally a metastasis 
in this area cannot be completely excluded. 
  
There is no evidence of abnormal enhancement to indicate 
leptomeningeal 
disease. Diffuse high signal intensity in the bone marrow, 
possibly 
representing bone marrow replacement for fat. 
PET: IMPRESSION: 1. 2-cm intracranial lymphoma metastasis in the 
left frontal lobe. 2. Moderate intramuscular lymphoma disease in 
the left biceps and right psoas 3. Extensive lymphoma disease in 
the left calf with mild regional spread to the left thigh and 
left inguinal nodes.

dysfunction. Rare sharp waves were also seen in the left 
temporal 
region phase reversing at F7, which may be indicative of an area 
of 
cortical irritability, but no clear electrographic seizures were 
seen. 
A breach rhythm was also noted in the left frontal temporal area 
likely 
due to a skull defect. Otherwise, the waking background was slow 
and 
disorganized with bursts of generalized slowing indicative of a 
mild to 
moderate encephalopathy. Toxic/metabolic disturbances, 
infections, and 
medication effects are among the most frequent causes of 
encephalopathy. 
CXR ___
IMPRESSION: Right-sided PICC line should be withdrawn 
approximately 3 cm for more optimal positioning. 
EEG ___
IMPRESSION: This is an abnormal 24-hour video EEG telemetry due 
to the 
presence of rare epileptiform discharges in the left temporal 
region 
indicative of an area of cortical irritability; however, no 
clear 
electrographic seizures were seen. Focal slowing was also seen 
in the 
same region along with higher amplitude activity due to a breach 
effect 
typically associated with skull defects. The background was 
better 
developed reaching a maximum of 8 Hz during the recording and 
more 
wakeful periods were seen overall. Overall, this record is 
improved 
compared to the previous day. 
MRI HEAD ___

1. No evidence of a second lesion in the temporal lobe. 
2. Increase in the volume of enhancing material and in 
surrounding edema in the left frontal lobe. This may represent 
tumor progression, or early 
response to radiation.

appears

Echo Conclusions:
The patient exercised for 7 minutes 0 seconds according to a 
___ treadmill protocol ___ METS) reaching a peak heart rate of 
105 bpm and a peak blood pressure of 175/78 mmHg. The test was 
stopped because of fatigue. This level of exercise represents an 
average exercise tolerance for age. In response to stress, the 
ECG showed ischemic ST changes (see exercise report for 
details). There were normal blood pressure and blunted heart 
rate responses to stress. 
.
Resting images were acquired at a heart rate of 62 bpm and a 
blood pressure of 140/80 mmHg. These demonstrated regional left 
ventricular systolic dysfunction with basal to distal 
inferolateral hypokinesis. (LVEF = 50 %). Right ventricular free 
wall motion is normal. Doppler demonstrated moderate mitral 
regurgitation with no aortic stenosis, aortic regurgitation or 
significant resting LVOT gradient. 
Echo images were acquired within 55 seconds after peak stress at 
heart rates of 92 - 105 bpm. Baseline abnormalities persist with 
new hypokinesis of the distal inferior wall and apex . There was 
augmentation of right ventricular free wall motion. 

IMPRESSION: Average functional exercise capacity. Ischemic ECG 
changes and 2D echocardiographic evidence of inducible ischemia 
to achieved workload.

atrial pressure is at least 15 mmHg. Left ventricular wall 
thicknesses are normal. The left ventricular cavity is severely

normal. The right ventricular cavity is dilated with depressed

pulmonary artery systolic pressure may be underestimated due to 
a very high right atrial pressure.] The end-diastolic pulmonic

diastolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. There 
is an anterior space which most likely represents a prominent 
fat pad.

Marked left ventricular mechanical dyssynchrony is present. 
However, marked ventricular interaction with reverse Bernheim 
phenomenon is also seen, due to marked right ventricular 
pressure and volume overload.

both ventricles are even more dilated, and severe mitral and

ventricular dyssynchrony remains evident.

seen. The mitral valve appears structurally normal with trivial

___ CARDIAC CATH ___:
The coronary circulation is right dominant. 
- Left main: normal
- Ostial LAD: there was a discrete 60% stenosis
- Circumflex: Angiography showed minor luminal irregularities
- ___ obtuse marginal: The vessel was small sized. There was a 
discrete 95% stenosis at the ostium of the vessel segment.
- Proximal ramus intermedius. There was a diffuse 20% stenosis 
at the site of a prior stent.
- Mid RCA: There was a 0% stenosis at the site of a prior stent. 
In a second lesion, there was a tubular 20% stenosis.

Lesion Intervention: A percutaneous intervention was performed 
on the 60% lesion in the proximal LAD. Following intervention 
there was a 60% residual stenosis. This was an ACC/AHA "non-high 
risk" lesion for intervention. There was TIMI 3 flow before the 
procedure and TIMI 3 flow after the procedure. There was no 
acute vessel closure. There was no perforation. There was no 
dissection. 

TTE ___
The left atrium is elongated. Left ventricular wall thicknesses 
and cavity size are normal. There is mild regional left 
ventricular systolic dysfunction with focal hypokinesis of the 
basal to mid inferior wall. The remaining segments contract 
normally (LVEF = 55 %). Tissue Doppler imaging suggests a normal 
left ventricular filling pressure (PCWP<12mmHg). There is a mild 
resting left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. There is no 
ventricular septal defect. The right ventricular cavity is 
mildly dilated The diameters of aorta at the sinus, ascending 
and arch levels are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are 
mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. No aortic 
regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are 
structurally normal. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Trivial 
mitral regurgitation is seen. The pulmonary artery systolic 
pressure could not be determined. There is no pericardial 
effusion. 

IMPRESSION: Suboptimal image quality. Regional left ventricular 
systolic dysfunction c/w CAD. Mild right ventricular cavity 
dilation. RV function difficult to assess given limited acoustic 
windows

surrounding encephalomalacic changes, most likely represents old

MRI OF THE HEAD:
There are hypointense areas noted in the C2 and the C3 vertebral 
bodies on the sagittal T1-weighted sequence, which are 
inadequately evaluated on the present study.
Focal hypointense area in the right periatrial region, 
posteriorly (series 11, image 11) on the FLAIR sequence, with 
hyperintense signal on the T2-weighted sequence, likely 
represents encephalomalacic gliotic changes, related to old 
infarct. Similarly, in the left cerebellar hemisphere, there is 
a slight irregular linear focus, hypointense on the T2-weighted 
images (series 11, image 7), which can represent a small linear 
focus of scarring.
There are no areas of restricted diffusion, to suggest acute 
infarction.
3D TOF MR ANGIOGRAM OF THE HEAD: This study is limited due to 
motion artifacts. Within these limitations, the major 
intracranial arteries are patent. No focal flow-limiting 
stenosis or occlusion is noted within the limitations of the 
study. Slightly prominent basilar tip, and its termination, is 
likely related to infundibula at the origins of the posterior 
cerebral arteries.
Contour irregularity of the cavernous internal carotid arteries 
is noted, likely related to atherosclerotic disease. More 
accurate assessment for focal stenosis is limited due to 
artifacts.
IMPRESSION:
1. No evidence of acute infarction.
2. Major intracranial arteries are patent, within the 
limitations of motion artifacts, significantly limiting more 
accurate assessment for focal stenosis or tiny aneurysms.
3. Evidence of sequelae of chronic small vessel occlusive 
disease and old infarct in the right posterior periatrial 
region.
4. Hypointense areas in the C2 and C3 bodies as seen on the 
sagittal T1 W sequence are inadequately evaluated on the present 
study. These can be related to marrow disorder or focal 
neoplastic etiology. These can be better evaluated with MR ___ 
spine. Medications On Admission: ALL: NKDA

Studies:
___ ___ ___ VASCULAR EMBOLIZA 
PROCEDURE:  1. Right common femoral artery access. 
2. SMA arteriogram. 
3. Celiac arteriogram. 
4. Cone beam CT right hepatic arteriogram. 
5. Cone beam CT left hepatic arteriogram. 
6. Coil embolization of the right gastric artery. 
7. Amplatzer plug embolization of the left hepatic as well as 
left gastric 
arteries. 
8. Left gastric arteriogram. 
9. Celiac axis arteriogram. 
10. Aortogram. 
11. Right common femoral arteriogram and Angio-Seal closure of 
right common 
femoral artery 
PROCEDURE DETAILS: 
Following the discussion of the risks, benefits and alternatives 
to the 
procedure, written informed consent was obtained from the 
patient. The patient was then brought to the angiography suite 
and placed supine on the exam table.
 
A pre-procedure time-out was performed per ___ protocol. 
Using palpatory and fluoroscopic guidance, the right common 
femoral artery was punctured using a micropuncture set at the 
level of the mid femoral head. A 0.018 wire was passed easily 
into the vessel lumen. A small skin incision was made over the 
needle. Then the inner dilator and wire removed and a 0.035 
___ wire was advanced under fluoroscopy into the aorta. The 
micropuncture sheath was exchanged for a 5 ___ sheath which 
was attached to a continuous heparinized saline side arm flush. 
A C2 cobra catheter was advanced over ___ wire into the 
aorta. The wire was removed and the SMA was selectively 
cannulated and small contrast injection was made to confirm 
position. SMA arteriogram was performed. The catheter was 
removed and the celiac artery was selectively cannulated and a 
small contrast injection was made to confirm position. A celiac 
arteriogram was performed. This demonstrated a replaced left 
hepatic artery from left gastric artery. To further characterize 
the anatomy, a cone beam CT was performed at the right and left 
hepatic arteries. Attempts to advance the C2 catheter and a 
glidewire into the left gastric artery were unsuccessful. The C2 
catheter was exchanged for ___ 1 glide catheter which was 
eventually advanced into the left gastric artery. Using an STC 
micro catheter and a double angled glidewire, the left hepatic 
artery was selected and an arteriogram was performed. This 
demonstrated branching of the right gastric artery from left 
hepatic artery. The micro wire and catheter were advanced into 
the left hepatic artery and then into the right gastric artery. 
3 x 3 hilum coils were deployed at this location. The first coil 
was deployed within the right gastric artery. The second coiled 
was partially deployed in the right gastric artery and partially 
in the left hepatic artery. 
Further injections of contrast demonstrated diminished flow in 
the left 
hepatic artery and therefore nitroglycerin and heparin were 
injected to 
restore flow. Multiple attempts were made to snare the left 
hepatic artery  oil were unsuccessful. In part, due to unstable 
access at the celiac artery. At that time, the patient was 
uncomfortable on the table due to prolonged procedure time and 
anesthesia was consulted. The patient was intubated and the 
procedure was continued under general anesthesia. 
Subsequently, the existing 5 ___ sheath was exchanged for a 5 
___/ 65 cm sheath which was advanced into the left hepatic 
artery over ___ wire to provide more secure access. More 
attempts were made to snare the coil out were unsuccessful. 
Injection of contrast demonstrated an extraluminal blush 
however, the patient was hemodynamically stable. At that time, 
transplant surgery was consulted and suggested close monitoring 
given the patient's stability. We decided to embolize the left 
gastric artery (trunk that provides supply to the left hepatic 
artery) to prevent potential peritoneal bleeding. A 6mm 
Amplatzer plug was used to embolize the left hepatic artery an 8 
mm Amplatzer plug was used to embolize the left gastric artery 
(trunk). A celiac arteriogram was performed and demonstrated 
occluded left gastric, patent common hepatic and splenic 
arteries but stasis of contrast at the celiac axis suggesting 
focal dissection. There was antegrade flow to the splenic and 
the right hepatic arteries. Attempts to pass a wire into the 
celiac axis to place a stent were unsuccessful. The patient 
remained hemodynamically stable. 
Aortogram was performed to delineate the anatomy. At that time, 
we decided to conclude the procedure and monitor the patient 
clinically. 
A Common femoral arteriogram was performed prior to use of a 
closure device. All catheters and wires were removed and a 6 
___ Angio-Seal device was deployed. Manual pressure was held 
until hemostasis was achieved. The patient tolerated the 
procedure. 
CONE BEAM CT: A rotational angiogram and cone beam CT were 
performed of the right and left hepatic arteries.  Multiplanar 
reformatted images were 
reconstructed, including volume-rendered images, using an 
independent 
workstation and were specifically evaluated and processed by the Medications On Admission: The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.

STUDIES
=========
TTE (___):  The left atrium is elongated. The right atrium is 
markedly dilated. The estimated right atrial pressure is at 
least 15 mmHg. Left ventricular wall thicknesses are normal. The 
left ventricular cavity is moderately dilated. There is severe 
regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction (see map; only 
the basal anterior and lateral walls are relatively spared) 
(quantiative biplane LVEF = 13%). The estimated cardiac index is 
borderline low (2.0-2.5L/min/m2). No masses or thrombi are seen 
in the left ventricle. Tissue Doppler imaging suggests an 
increased left ventricular filling pressure (PCWP>18mmHg). The 
right ventricular cavity is markedly dilated with severe global 
free wall hypokinesis. The ascending aorta is mildly dilated. 
The aortic arch is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets (3) 
are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. No 
aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are 
structurally normal. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Moderate 
(2+) mitral regurgitation is seen. Due to the eccentric nature 
of the regurgitant jet, its severity may be significantly 
underestimated (Coanda effect). The tricuspid valve leaflets are 
mildly thickened. Moderate to severe [3+] tricuspid 
regurgitation is seen. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic 
pressure is normal. [In the setting of at least moderate to 
severe tricuspid regurgitation, the estimated pulmonary artery 
systolic pressure may be underestimated due to a very high right 
atrial pressure.] The pulmonic valve leaflets are thickened. The 
end-diastolic pulmonic regurgitation velocity is increased 
suggesting pulmonary artery diastolic hypertension. There is no 
pericardial effusion. 

IMPRESSION: Moderately dilated left ventricle with severe 
regional and global dysfunction. At least moderate mitral 
regurgitation. Dilated right ventricle with severe free wall 
hypokinesis. Moderate to severe tricuspid regurgitation. 
Pulmonary hypertension (extent not able to be quantified). 
Mildly dilated thoracic aorta. 

ABDOMINAL ULTRASOUND (___):  IMPRESSION:  1.  
Cholelithiasis.  Mild gallbladder wall thickening and 
pericholecystic fluid is likely related to third spacing related 
to the patient's known heart failure. 2.  Nodular contour of the 
liver, unchanged from the prior CT.  Normal echogenicity.  3.  
Normal kidneys.

CT CHEST W/O CONTRAST (___):  IMPRESSION:

1. Right Swan-Ganz catheter identified with the distal tip in 
the right lower lobe pulmonary artery. This needs to be 
retracted back to the level of the right ventricular outflow 
tract.
2. Severe cardiomegaly with four-chamber enlargement. AICD 
device identified.
3. Dense coronary artery calcifications.
4. Moderate centrilobular emphysema predominate within the upper 
lobes.
5. Slightly nodular contour of the liver, suggestive of 
cirrhosis.
6. Thickening of adrenal glands bilaterally, likely in keeping 
with adrenal
hyperplasia.
7. Small amount of fluid/ stranding identified surrounding the 
pancreatic head near the porta hepatis, not completely assess, 
likely related to trace ascites rather than pancreatitis in the 
absence of clinical history of abdominal pain.

with

dilation present.

few
associated neutrophils.

with
satisfactory positive control.

Hemodynamics (see above): Mild pulmonary hypertension (44/24/32
mm Hg) with markedly elevated PCW of 25 mm Hg with prominent V
wave superimposed on what appeared to be a partial PA waveform
suggesting significant mitral regurgitation. Despite several
attempts with small balloon volumes, no better PCW waveform 
could
be obtained. The true PASP and RVSP were difficult to ascertain
due to catheter fling. Using an assumed oxygen consumption and 
an
imputed arterial oxygen saturation, the CI was reduced at 1.7
L/min/m2.

Assessment & Recommendations
 1. Severely elevated PCW consistent with severe left 
ventricular
diastolic heart failure in setting of known severe left
ventricular systolic heart failure.
 2. Severe right ventricular diastolic heart failure.
 3. Mild pulmonary hypertension.
 4. No oxymetric evidence of significant right-to-left shunting
and likely no significant left-to-right shunting.
 5. Markedly depressed cardiac index.
 6. RFV sheath to be removed.
 7. Additional plans per Heart Failure Service. Reinforce
secondary preventative measures against CAD and LV systolic and
diastolic heart failure.

FINDINGS: 
Left median motor nerve conduction studies shows normal distal 
latency, mild-to-moderately reduced response amplitudes, and 
mildly decreased conduction velocity. F-response minimum latency 
was mildly prolonged.

conduction velocity in the leg, and mildly reduced conduction 
velocity across the knee. F-response minimum latency was normal.

including F waves.

decreased response amplitude and normal conduction velocity.

amplitude and mildly decreased conduction velocity. 
  
Right sural nerve conduction study was normal. 
  
Concentric needle electromyography (EMG) of left deltoid showed 
mild chronic reinnervation, moderate fasciculation potentials, 
with slight-to- moderately reduced recruitment in deltoid. 
  
EMG of left biceps, triceps, and abductor pollicis brevis showed 
mild, chronic reinnervation, moderate ongoing denervation, 
moderate fasciculations, and slightly reduced recruitment.

reinnervation and severe ongoing denervation.

reinnervation, mild ongoing denervation, and moderate 
fasciculation potentials.

showed moderate, chronic reinnervation, moderate fasciculations, 
and moderately-to-markedly reduced recruitment in tibialis 
anterior.

mild ongoing denervation, and moderate fasciculations with 
slightly-to-moderately reduced recruitment.

reinnervation, mild ongoing denervation, and 
moderately-to-markedly reduced recruitment.

reinnervation, mild fasciculations, complex repetitive 
discharges, and slightly reduced 
recruitment.

patient's 
inability to fully relax. 
   
EMG of left masseter was normal. 
  
EMG of left mid-thoracic paraspinal muscles showed severe 
ongoing denervation. 
  
IMPRESSION: 
Abnormal study. The electrophysiologic evidence is consistent 
with a disorder of motor neurons or their axons. In addition, 
the electrophysiologic data is  suggestive of a mild, 
generalized, sensorimotor polyneuropathy with axonal  features.

ENDOSCOPY:
----------

EGD ___

stomach pouch was small. The GJ anastomosis was carefully 
examined and appears intact, with no ulcers. (biopsy: normal)
Normal mucosa in the duodenum (biopsy: normal)
Otherwise normal EGD to jejunum

EUS ___
Linear EUS was performed with the Olympus enchoendoscope at 
7.5mHz. A focused/limited EUS evaluation was possible given the 
gastric bypass anatomy, which does not allow EUS visualization 
from the duodenal bulb (for critical distal biliary and 
ampullary view). The PD was measured at 2.2mm in the body, and 
2.5mm in the head, which is normal diameter. The intrahepatic 
biliary system was slightly dilated, and the extrahepatic 
CHD/CBD was only mildly dilated (maximum diameter 7.8mm), within 
the normal limits for post CCY state. The CBD cannot be traced 
to the ampulla because of the gastric bypass anatomy. No filling 
defects or mass is seen.
Limited eval with EUS scope notable for gastric bypass anatomy 

Recommendations: Will need careful review of prior CT scans from 
___ and ___. Biliary dilation is 
likely benign/post CCY. This can often be more prominent after 
gastric bypass ___ et al J. Gastro Surg ___. It is 
important to demonstrate stability over time. If prior scans 
show no biliary dilation, then can consider single balloon to 
evaluate ampulla and further surveillance imaging to rule out 
mass.

Left Ventricle - Septal Peak E':  *0.05 m/s  > 0.08 m/s  
Left Ventricle - Ratio E/E':  9  < 15  
Aorta - Sinus Level:  3.3 cm  <= 3.6 cm  
Aortic Valve - Peak Velocity:  1.9 m/sec  <= 2.0 m/sec  
Aortic Valve - LVOT VTI:  24     
Aortic Valve - LVOT diam:  2.3 cm     
Mitral Valve - E Wave:  0.6 m/sec     
Mitral Valve - A Wave:  0.8 m/sec     
Mitral Valve - E/A ratio:  0.75     
Mitral Valve - E Wave deceleration time:  219 ms  140-250 ms  
 
Findings  
RIGHT ATRIUM/INTERATRIAL SEPTUM: No ASD by 2D or color Doppler. 

LEFT VENTRICLE: Mild symmetric LVH with normal cavity size and 
global systolic function (LVEF>55%). Suboptimal technical 
quality, a focal LV wall motion abnormality cannot be fully 
excluded. Estimated cardiac index is normal (>=2.5L/min/m2). 
Doppler parameters are indeterminate for LV diastolic function. 
No resting LVOT gradient. 

RIGHT VENTRICLE: Normal RV chamber size. Borderline normal RV 
systolic function. 

AORTA: Normal aortic diameter at the sinus level. Focal 
calcifications in aortic root. 

AORTIC VALVE: Mildly thickened aortic valve leaflets (3). No AS. 
No AR. 

MITRAL VALVE: Mildly thickened mitral valve leaflets. No MVP. 
Calcified tips of papillary muscles. 

TRICUSPID VALVE: Normal tricuspid valve leaflets with trivial 
TR. Normal PA systolic pressure. 

PULMONIC VALVE/PULMONARY ARTERY: Normal pulmonic valve leaflet. 
No PS. Physiologic PR. 

PERICARDIUM: No pericardial effusion. 

GENERAL COMMENTS: Frequent atrial premature beats.  
Conclusions  
No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. There is 
mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity 
size and global systolic function (LVEF>60%). Due to suboptimal 
technical quality, a focal wall motion abnormality cannot be 
fully excluded. The estimated cardiac index is normal 
(>=2.5L/min/m2). Doppler parameters are indeterminate for left 
ventricular diastolic function. Right ventricular chamber size 
is normal with borderline low systolic free wall function. The 
aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic 
stenosis is not present. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The 
mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is no mitral 
valve prolapse. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure 
is normal. There is no pericardial effusion. 

IMPRESSION: Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with 
preserved global ventricular systolic function. Normal right 
ventricular cavity size with borderline low free wall systolic 
function.   

CXR FINDINGS:  As compared to the previous examination, there is 
now evidence of normal lung volumes without evidence of fibrotic 
changes.  Status post sternotomy with unchanged sternotomy 
wires.  Calcified granuloma at the right upper lobe base.  
Borderline size of the cardiac silhouette without overt 
pulmonary edema.  Moderate tortuosity of the thoracic aorta.  No 
evidence of pneumonia.  No signs suggesting pulmonary fibrosis.

Conclusions  

The left atrium is normal in size. The IVC was not well seen for 
assessment of RA pressure. Left ventricular wall thickness, 
cavity size, and global systolic function are normal (LVEF>55%). 
Regional left ventricular wall motion is normal. Right 
ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The 
aortic root is mildly dilated at the sinus level. The aortic 
valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened. There is no aortic 
valve stenosis. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral 
valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Trivial mitral 
regurgitation is seen. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic 
pressure ___ mmHg above right atrial pressure. There is no 
pericardial effusion.

Conclusions  
Pre-CPB:
The left atrium is mildly dilated. No thrombus is seen in the 
left atrial appendage. No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or 
color Doppler. Left ventricular wall thicknesses are normal. 
Overall left ventricular systolic function is low normal (LVEF 
50-55%). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are 
normal. 

The descending thoracic aorta is mildly dilated. There are 
complex (>4mm) atheroma in the descending thoracic aorta. No 
thoracic aortic dissection is seen. The aortic valve leaflets 
(3) are mildly thickened. No aortic regurgitation is seen. 

The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There appear to 
be some filamentous structures associated with the mitral 
leaflets that are seen in the left atrium, possibly representing 
ruptured tertiary chordae. Mitral leaflet morphology remains 
normal. Mild mitral regurgitation is seen. 

Dr. ___ was notified in person of the results at time 
of study.

Post-CPB:
Left ventricular systolic function remains low-normal. Estimated 
EF is 50%. RV systolic function is preserved. 

The MR remains mild. Other valvular function remains unchanged. 
There is no evidence of aortic dissection.

CARDIOLOGY:
ECHO ___:
Conclusions
The left atrium is normal in size. The right atrium is 
moderately dilated. No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or 
color Doppler. There is mild symmetric left ventricular 
hypertrophy with normal cavity size. There is mild regional left 
ventricular systolic dysfunction with basal to mid inferior 
dyskinesis and basal to mid inferolateral hypokinesis/akinesis. 
Doppler parameters are most consistent with Grade II (moderate) 
left ventricular diastolic dysfunction. The remaining left 
ventricular segments contract normally. Right ventricular 
chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The aortic valve 
leaflets are moderately thickened. There is no aortic valve 
stenosis. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve 
leaflets are mildly thickened. There is partial posterior mitral 
leaflet flail. An eccentric, anteriorly directed jet of Moderate 
(2+) mitral regurgitation is seen. Due to the eccentric nature 
of the regurgitant jet, its severity may be significantly 
underestimated (Coanda effect). The tricuspid valve leaflets are 
mildly thickened. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic 
pressure is normal. There is no pericardial effusion. There is 
an anterior space which most likely represents a prominent fat 
pad.

IMPRESSION: Mild symmetric LVH with regional left ventricular 
systolic dysfunction consistent with CAD. Probable partial flail 
of the posterior leaflet of the mitral valve with consequent at 
least moderate mitral regurgitation that is directed anteriorly. 
Normal right ventricular function.

COMMENTS:     
1. Selective coronary angiography of this right dominant system
demonstrated severe, diffuse left coronary artery disease. The 
___ had
an 80% distal stenosis. The LAD had an 80% proximal stenosis 
followed by
a 100% stenosis in its mid portion. The LCx had a 100% stenosis 
after
OM1, and OM1 had a 60% stenosis at its origin. The RCA was not
visualized as it is known to be chronically occluded.
2. Arterial conduit angiography demonstrated no angiographically
apparent, flow-limiting stenosis of the LIMA graft to LAD. There 
were
patent collaterals to RCA and LCx.
3. Venous conduit angiography was deferred, as all three SVGs 
are known
to be chronically occluded.
 
FINAL DIAGNOSIS:    
1. Left main and three vessel coronary artery disease.
2. LIMA graft to LAD with no angiographically apparent, 
flow-limiting
stenoses, with patent collaterals to RCA and LCx.

versus

infarcts or nonhemorrhagic diffuse axonal injury.

microhemorrhage, as there is no associated acute diffusion 
abnormality.

associated

PREBYPASS:
The left atrium is normal in size.
Left ventricular wall thickness, cavity size and regional/global 
systolic function are normal (LVEF >55%). 
Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. 
The diameters of aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels 
are normal. 
The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with 
good leaflet excursion and no aortic stenosis or aortic 
regurgitation. 
A large aneurysm is noted at the level of the left subclavian 
takeoff. The remainder of the descending aorta is of normal 
caliber.

Imaging
==========

___ Endoscopic ultrasound 
IMPRESSIONS 
___ D Esophagitis
EUS : The parenchyma in the uncinate, head, body and tail of the 
pancreas was homogenous, with a normal salt and pepper 
appearance.
Normal main pancreatic duct
The bile duct and pancreatic duct were imaged and appeared 
normal.
Mass: An ill defined, 4 cm X 6 cm irregular, hypoechoeic and 
heterogenous in echotexture was found arising from the duodenal 
wall.  The lesion involved the mucosa, submucosa and the 
muscularis.  Few ''pseudopodia'' were noted along the outer 
border of the muscularis propria - these were suspicious for 
tumor extension beyond the muscularis layer.  FNA was performed  

Cold forceps biopsies were performed for histology.

___ CTA abd/pelvis 
1. Circumferential wall thickening of the third portion of the 
duodenum with
an enhancing soft tissue mass, most likely duodenal in origin. 
There is no fat plane with the otherwise normal appearing 
pancreas. Small retroperitoneal lymph nodes do not meet size 
criteria for pathologic enlargement. No other evidence of 
lymphadenopathy or local invasion.
2. Diverticulosis.
3. Please see the separately submitted report of the same day CT 
Chest forfindings above the diaphragm.

___  CT Chest with contrast 
1. A 1.5 cm low-density pulmonary lesion in the right lower lobe 
is suspicious
for Bronchocele distal to a strictured or atretic bronchus or a 
small
endobronchial mass.  Any prior imaging of the chest, including 
remote chest
radiographs should be consulted to determine its chronicity and 
the need for
further imaging.
2. Other multiple pulmonary nodules are 5 mm or less.  Some of 
the lower lobe
nodules included on prior CT abdomen and pelvis from ___ are 
larger since
then.
3. New mild pulmonary edema as evidenced by ground-glass 
opacities and
interlobular septal thickening.
4. Anterior mediastinal soft tissue lesion may be thymoma or 
thymic
hyperplasia.  If clinically indicated, consider MRI for better 
evaluation.
5. Moderate emphysema.

IMAGING
CT Abdomen ___
IMPRESSION: 
  
1.  Findings consistent with acute right-sided colitis, possibly 
infectious, inflammatory, or ischemic in nature.  No evidence of 
perforation or pneumatosis. 
2.  2.3 cm region of hyperenhancement at the junction of the 
descending and sigmoid colon, nonspecific in nature, although an 
underlying mass lesion cannot be excluded.  Correlation with 
colonoscopy is recommended. 
3.  7 mm left lower lobe pulmonary nodule should be followed up 
with CT in six months if this patient has no history of smoking 
or malignancy.  Otherwise, a followup CT in three months is 
recommended. 
4.  Evidence of hepatic steatosis. 
5.  Mild central intrahepatic biliary duct dilatation with mild 
dilatation of the common duct, not unexpected in a patient 
status post cholecystectomy.  Left hepatic lobe pneumobilia 
should be correlated with a history of 
sphincterotomy. 
6.  Increased bilateral adrenal gland thickening.  No focal 
adrenal nodule identified.

___ Imaging PELVIS (AP ONLY) 
FINDINGS:  
The osseous structures are diffusely demineralized which limits 
the detection of subtle fractures. The previously demonstrated 
right inferior pubic ramus fracture and right parasymphyseal 
fracture appear similar compared to the previous CT, and are 
nondisplaced. Patient's known right sacral fracture is not well 
assessed on the current exam as overlying bowel gas obscures 
assessment of the sacrum. No new fractures are otherwise 
visualized. There are mild degenerative changes of both hips 
with joint space narrowing. No dislocation is present. No 
concerning lytic or sclerotic osseous abnormalities are 
visualized.  
IMPRESSION:  Right parasymphyseal and right inferior pubic ramus 
nondisplaced fractures are unchanged. Known right sacral 
fracture is not well assessed on the current radiograph. No new 
fracture or dislocation.

FINDINGS: There is no intra-axial or extra-axial hemorrhage, 
mass, midline shift, or acute vascular territorial infarct.

sulci are prominent compatible global volume loss. Included 
paranasal sinuses and mastoids are clear. Skull and extracranial 
soft tissues are unremarkable.

seen on the prior study. Recommend outpatient chest CT for 
further evaluation for possible pulmonary nodule.Slight blunting

Chest CT:
1. Possible nodule in the left mid lung reported on recent chest 
radiograph does not have a correlate on CT and may represent 
costochondral calcification shadows. Biapical pleuroparenchymal 
scarring. 
2. Focal esophageal wall thickening in the upper/mid segment 
should be 
correlated with direct visualization. 
3. Heterogeneous left thyroid lobe can be further evaluated with 
ultrasound if clinically indicated. 

CT abdomen Pelvis:
No acute intra-abdominal process and no significant change 
compared to the prior examination. 2. Whirling of the abdominal 
mesentery without evidence of obstruction or ischemia is of 
unclear significance. 

CT head: No acute intracranial abnormality

MRI Head: No acute infarction. Stable chronic supratentorial 
white matter and pons signal abnormalities are most likely 
sequela of chronic small vessel ischemic disease, given the 
patient's age. Otherwise, motion limited exam without evidence 
for other acute abnormalities or mass 

EEG ___: This is an abnormal video-EEG monitoring session 
because of 
rhythmic delta activity which evolves and lasts up to 30 seconds 
notably 
during sleep, occasional generalized bifrontally predominant 
discharges, and rare bioccipital discharges. The background 
slowing is indicative of global cerebral dysfunction with areas 
of focal neuronal dysfunction and cortical irritability. These 
findings are concerning for an epileptiform encephalopathy with 
recurrent brief nonconvulsive seizures which self-resolve. The 
record improves towards the latter half of the study. 

EEG ___:
This is an abnormal video-EEG monitoring session because of 
occasional rhythmic delta activity, with periods of triphasic 
wNaves 
morphology, which waxes and wanes notably during sleep, and rare 
isolated 
independent and very rare synchronous bitemporal discharges. 
These findings indicate global cerebral dysfunction along with 
focal cortical irritability in both temporal regions. The former 
can be seen in conditions such as toxic metabolic 
encephalopathy. The background slowing is notably improved and 
is likely indicative of generalized mild encephalopathy. No 
electrographic seizures are recorded. Overall, this is a 
significantly improved record as compared to the prior study.

___ CXR PA/L:  
Enlarged cardiomediastinal silhouette. Mild pulmonary vascular 
congestion. Subtle right base opacity most likely relates to 
vascular congestion although underlying infection is difficult 
to exclude.  

___ NCHCT:  
No acute intracranial process. Possible subtle ectasia of the 
distal left vertebral artery and proximal basilar artery.  
EKG: NSR @ 69 bpm, normal axis, incomplete RBBB, LVH w/ 
secondary repolarization abnormalities, LAE  

___ Renal artery Doppler:
No evidence of renal artery stenosis in the left kidney and 
likely no stenosis in the right kidney however the Doppler 
examination is somewhat limited due to the patient's limited 
ability to hold his breath. 

___ TTE:
The left atrial volume index is moderately increased. The 
estimated right atrial pressure is ___ mmHg. There is severe 
symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy. The left ventricular 
cavity size is normal. Overall left ventricular systolic 
function is mildly depressed (Quantitative (biplane) LVEF = 46%) 
secondary to mild global hypokinesis with slightly worse 
function of the basal-mid inferior and inferoseptal walls. 
Tissue Doppler imaging suggests an increased left ventricular 
filling pressure (PCWP>18mmHg). Right ventricular chamber size 
and free wall motion are normal. The right ventricular free wall 
is hypertrophied. The aortic root is mildly dilated at the sinus 
level. The ascending aorta is mildly dilated. The aortic arch is 
mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear 
structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic 
stenosis or aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve leaflets are 
structurally normal. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Mild 
(1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. There is mild pulmonary 
artery systolic hypertension. The end-diastolic pulmonic 
regurgitation velocity is increased suggesting pulmonary artery 
diastolic hypertension. There is a very small pericardial 
effusion. There are no echocardiographic signs of tamponade. 

 IMPRESSION: Severe concentric left ventricular hypertrophy with 
mildly depressed global and regional systolic dysfunction and 
increased filling pressure. Mild mitral regurgitation. Mild 
pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. Mild dilatation of the 
ascending aorta and arch. Very small pericardial effusion.

 Findings are suggestive of hypertensive myopathy (with possible 
underlying CAD), although an infiltrative process cannot be 
excluded. Medications On Admission: None

CT CHEST ___:  IMPRESSION:  
  
1. Extensive, confluent, bilateral airspace consolidations, most 
appreciable in the right middle and lower lobes, suggestive of 
pneumonia.

3. Mediastinal lymphadenopathy, likely reactive in nature. 
4. Contrast opacification of the esophagus suggesting reflux.  
Although not necessarily related to pneumonia, the possibility 
of aspiration as an 
underlying cause could also be considered in the appropriate 
setting in 
addition to community acquired pneumonia. 
5.  Emphysema. 

TTE ___: Conclusions  
Left ventricular wall thicknesses and cavity size are normal. 
Due to suboptimal technical quality, a focal wall motion 
abnormality cannot be fully excluded. Overall left ventricular 
systolic function is low normal (LVEF 50-55%). The right 
ventricular cavity is dilated with depressed free wall 
contractility. The aortic valve is not well seen. The mitral 
valve leaflets are not well seen. Trivial mitral regurgitation 
is seen. The pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be 
determined. There is a trivial/physiologic pericardial effusion. 


IMPRESSION: Suboptimal image quality. Normal left ventricular 
cavity size with low normal global systolic function in the 
setting of marked tachycardia. Right ventricular cavity dilation 
with free wall hypkinesis. Valvular anatomy and function could 
not be assessed, but severe aortic stenosis and mitral stenosis 
do not appear to be present.   

RUQ US ___: IMPRESSION: 
1. Echogenic liver consistent with steatosis. Other forms of

steatohepatitis cannot be excluded on the basis of this 
examination.

rule out infection due to other L.pneumophila serogroups or 
other Legionella species. Furthermore, in infected patients the 
excretion of antigen in urine may vary.

dysfunction dating back to his chemotherapy/radiation as a 
child, and had not been taking any of his cardiac meds. Last EF 
was normal in ___, though EF was depressed to 35% with infusion 
of dobutamine during a ___ stress echo. For his heart failure 
he was started on a Lasix drip, and intermittently required 
levophed and inotropic support with dobutamine. He exhibited 
brisk diuresis with large volume UOP. He was successfully 
extubated on ___. His Lasix was transitioned to 80 mg PO 
Lasix, and he was started on low doses of metoprolol and ACE 
inhibitor. EF recovered to 26% prior to discharge with ECHO 
showing global hypokinesis. Ultimately he likely had a 
preexisting cardiomyopathy that was worsened in the setting of 
recreational drug use (benzos and cocaine positive on 
admission).

Coronary Description
The coronary circulation is right dominant.
LM: The Left Main, arising from the left cusp, is a large 
caliber vessel. This vessel bifurcates into the Left Anterior 
Descending and Left Circumflex systems.
LAD: The Left Anterior Descending artery, which arises from the 
LM, is a large caliber vessel. There is a 50% stenosis in the 
proximal and mid segments. The Diagonal, arising from the 
proximal segment, is a medium caliber vessel.
Cx: The Circumflex artery, which arises from the LM, is a large 
caliber vessel. There is a 60% stenosis in the mid segment. The 
Obtuse Marginal, arising from the proximal segment, is a medium 
caliber vessel. The Atrioventricular Circumflex, arising from 
the distal segment, is a medium caliber vessel.
RCA: The Right Coronary Artery, arising from the right cusp, is 
a large caliber vessel. There is a 40% stenosis in the ostium. 
The Acute Marginal, arising from the proximal segment, is a 
small caliber vessel. The Right Posterolateral Artery, arising 
from the distal segment, is a medium caliber vessel. The Right 
Posterior Descending Artery, arising from the distal segment, is 
a medium caliber vessel.

IMPRESSION: Trace fluid in the acromioclavicular joint with 
minimal 
irregularity of the articular surfaces and large amount of edema 
in the 
trapezius and deltoid muscles. The spectrum of findings could be 
seen in the setting of acute injury as in a grade 1 sprain of 
the acromioclavicular joint.

are 
consistent with nonspecific myositis of the trapezius and 
deltoid muscles.  Given the trace amount of fluid in the 
acromioclavicular joint superimposed infection in this region 
cannot be excluded. The amount of fluid would not be amenable to 
image-guided joint aspiration. This would be an atypical 
location for diabetic myonecrosis.

C.CATH Study Date of ___ 1. Selective coronary angiography 
of this right dominant system revealed one vessel CAD. The LMCA 
was patent. The LAD was patent, but with slow flow suggestive of 
microvascular dysfunction and tortuous terminal vessels. The LCX 
was patent but with slow flow and tortuous terminal vessels. 
There was a single large OM2 and a modest LPL/OM5. The RCA had a 
short horizontal origin with early upward shepherd's crook bend. 
The distal RCA was diffusely small in caliber (suggestive of a 
spontaneous arterial dissection with a secondary hematoma 
compressing the lumen), with up to 75% narrowing extending to 
hazy filling defect at origin of RPDA/bifurcation with small 
distal AV groove RCA. There was a tortuous hairpin turn in the 
mid RPDA. 2. Limited resting hemodynamics demonstrated mildly 
elevated LVEDP of 15 mmHg and normal systemic arterial 
pressures. There was no transaortic gradient on catheter 
pullback from LV to aorta. 3. Left ventriculography demonstrated 
global hypokinesis, worse inferiorly and inferoapically. The 
calculated LVEF was 47%. There was no non-ectopic mitral 
regurgitation. 4. Successful PTCA and placement of bare-metal 
stents in the RCA were performed. The procedure was complicated 
by proximal-mid RCA dissection. Overlapping bare-metal stents 
were placed in the RCA (proximal-to-distal), with 4.0x12 mm 
Vision, 3.5x18 mm Driver, 3.0x30 mm Driver, 3.0x30 mm Driver, 
2.5x24 mm Micro Driver, 2.5x8 mm Micro Driver, and 2.25x24 mm 
Micro Driver.  Final angiography showed TIMI 2 flow in the RCA, 
slightly slow flow in the jailed AM branches, no residual 
stenoses in the stents, a slight amount of contrast staining 
outside of the proximal stents due to the dissection, and a mild 
(grade B) dissection in the proximal RPDA (See ___ Comments). 
5. Limited angiography of the right femoral artery showed the 
arteriotomy puncture site in the body of the right common 
femoral artery.  There was a corrugated appearance of the common 
femoral artery and the superficial femoral artery that was 
suggestive of fibromuscular dysplasia.  A 6 ___ Angioseal VIP 
was deployed successfully with good hemostasis. 6. Monitoring 
for radiation-induced skin injury is recommended given nominal 
IRP fluoroscopic skin exposure >4 Gy. FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. One 
vessel coronary artery disease, possibly due to spontaneous 
arterial dissection. 
2. Mild diffuse, heterogeneous left ventricular systolic 
dysfunction. 3. Mild left ventricular diastolic dysfunction. 4. 
Placement of bare-metal stents in the distal RCA. 5. PCI 
complicated by proximal-mid RCA dissection that was successfully 
rescued by placement of additional bare metal stents. 6. 
Possible fibromuscular dysplasia, based on the angiographic 
appearance of the right CFA and SFA. 7. Successful Angioseal 
closure of the right femoral arteriotomy. 8. Monitoring for 
radiation-induced skin injury is recommended given nominal IRP 
fluoroscopic skin exposure >4 Gy. 
.

Echo (___):
The left atrial volume index is normal. No atrial septal defect 
is seen by 2D or color Doppler. There is mild symmetric left 
ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size and 
regional/global systolic function (LVEF>55%). Right ventricular 
chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The ascending 
aorta is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are 
mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. Trace 
aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve appears 
structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. There is 
no mitral valve prolapse. The estimated pulmonary artery 
systolic pressure is high normal. There is no pericardial 
effusion. 

IMPRESSION: Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with 
preserved regional and global biventricular systolic function. 
Mildly dilated ascending aorta. No definite structural cardiac 
source of embolism identified.

MRI HEAD WITH AND WITHOUT CONTRAST (___):
1.  Left cerebellar hemispheric hemorrhage with mild mass effect 
on the fourth ventricle, but no evidence of hydrocephalus or 
herniation, 
  
2.  No definite underlying mass or evidence of cerebral venous 
thrombosis. 
  
3.  No large flow voids in the region of the hemorrhage to 
indicate a large underlying vascular malformation.

products, which may require ___ weeks.  However, given the 
scattered foci of susceptibility representing micro-bleeds, in 
quite typical locations, hypertensive hemorrhage is the likely 
etiology of both current and previous hemorrhage.

Patient was immediately taken to the cath lab where the culprit 
lesion was felt to be a 100% stenosis of the proximal RCA, for 
which a DES was placed. He was also noted to have 80% stenosis 
of the mid segment of the LAD, which was not intervened upon. 
The procedural course was complicated by worsening bradycardia 
and hypotension, thought likely to be a vagal response given 
increased sensitivity in the setting of his RCA lesion. 
Following intervention, his EKG returned to normal sinus rhythm, 
with symptomatic and hemodynamic improvement.

TTE ___:
The left atrium is moderately dilated. No left atrial 
mass/thrombus seen (best excluded by transesophageal 
echocardiography). The right atrium is dilated. Left ventricular 
wall thickness, cavity size, and global systolic function are 
normal (LVEF55%). [Intrinsic left ventricular systolic function 
is likely more depressed given the severity of mitral 
regurgitation.] The right ventricular cavity is mildly dilated 
with normal free wall contractility. [Intrinsic right 
ventricular systolic function is likely more depressed given the 
severity of tricuspid regurgitation.] The ascending aorta is 
moderately dilated. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly 
thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. Mild to moderate 
(___) aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets 
are mildly thickened. There is no mitral valve prolapse. 
Moderate to severe (3+) mitral regurgitation is seen. The 
tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Moderate to 
severe [3+] tricuspid regurgitation is seen. The estimated 
pulmonary artery systolic pressure is mildly increased. [In the 
setting of at least moderate to severe tricuspid regurgitation, 
the estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure may be 
underestimated due to a very high right atrial pressure.] There 
is a small to moderate sized circumferential pericardial 
effusion without evidence of hemodynamic compromise.

IMPRESSION: Moderate to severe mitral regurgitation. Moderate to 
severe tricuspid regurgitation. Pulmonary artery hypertension. 
Mild-moderate aortic regurgitation. Right ventricular cavity 
dilation with preserved free wall motion. Dilated ascending 
aorta.

Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of ___, 
the severity of mitral regurgitation has increased and the 
pericardial effusion is slightly smaller. The estimated PA 
systolic pressure is now slightly lower.

___ EEG IMPRESSION: This is an abnormal continuous ICU 
monitoring study because of a discontinuous background 
throughout the recording, characterized by ___ Hz theta 
frequency activity with admixed delta activity and occasional 
suppressions, consistent with a moderate to several 
encephalopathy. Background reactivity is present as seen during 
bedside examination when a more continuous and higher voltage 
theta frequency activity is observed. There are no definite 
epileptiform discharges or electrographic seizures. Note is made 
of an irregular cardiac rhythm throughout the recording with an 
average heart rate of 70 to 130 bpm on a single channel EKG. 

___ ECG Baseline artifact. Sinus tachycardia. Non-diagnostic Q 
waves in leads I and aVL. Borderline intraventricular conduction 
delay of the left bundle-branch block type. ST-T wave 
abnormalities. No previous tracing available for comparison. 
Clinical correlation is suggested. TRACING ___ CXR IMPRESSION: 1. Widened mediastinum may reflect low lung 
volumes and supine positioning, however mediastinal great vessel 
injury cannot be excluded. If concern exists, recommend chest 
CTA. 2. Pulmonary vascular congestion and probable mild 
pulmonary edema. 3. Bibasilar atelectasis. 4. ET tube with tip 6 
cm above carina. Enteric tube with tip projecting over stomach 
fundus. 

___ CT SPINE 1. No acute fracture or malalignment. 2. 
Heterogeneously enlarged left thyroid gland with punctate 
calcification suggestive of a goiter. Consider thyroid 
ultrasound if the patient has not had one previously if the 
patient's condition stabilizes. 3. Mild pulmonary edema. 

___ CT HEAD W/O CONTRAST IMPRESSION: 1. No acute intracranial 
hemorrhage or mass effect. 2. Subtle subcortical white matter 
hypodensity in the right frontal lobe which is nonspecific, 
potentially related to chronic small vessel infarction, but can 
also be seen with vasculitis, demyelination, or infection. This 
can be further assessed with MRI.

pulmonary embolism to the segmental level. 2. Fusiform dilation 
to 53 mm of the extrahepatic common hepatic and common bile duct

cyst. Hyperdense anti-dependent material within the gallbladder 
lumen may represent sludge, however underlying mass lesion is 
also of concern. Recommend non-urgent MRCP for further

was referred to the lab for evaluation of chest discomfort

throughout the study. The patient did report transient episodes 
of nausea throughout the study. There were no significant ST 
segment changes during the infusion or in recovery. The rhythm 
was sinus with rare isolated vpbs. In late recovery, there was 
an 8 beat run of a narrow complex PSVT. Appropriate hemodynamic 
response to the infusion and recovery. The dipyridamole was 
reversed with 125 mg of 
aminophylline IV.

report sent separately.

IMPRESSION:  1.  Mild fixed inferior wall defect most likely 
secondary to 
attenuation.  No additional myocardial perfusion defect.  
  
2.  Normal left ventricular ejection fraction of 64%. 

TTE ___: Conclusions  
The left atrium is mildly dilated. There is mild symmetric left 
ventricular hypertrophy. The left ventricular cavity size is 
normal. Due to suboptimal technical quality, a focal wall motion 
abnormality cannot be fully excluded. Overall left ventricular 
systolic function is normal (LVEF = 65%). Right ventricular 
chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The ascending 
aorta is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear 
structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic 
stenosis or aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve appears 
structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. The 
estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal. There is 
no pericardial effusion.

CT HEAD W/O CONTRAST (___)
An 8 mm hyperdensity is seen in the cerebellum on the left, 
likely 
representing an intraparenchymal hemorrhage or possibly a 
hyperdense lesion 
such as a vascular malformation which is considered less likely. 
Mild 
surrounding hypodensity is seen suggesting edema without 
significant mass 
effect.  There is no evidence of mass effect, or infarction.  
Prominent 
ventricles and sulci suggest age related involutional changes or 
atrophy.  
Periventricular white matter hypodensities are consistent with 
chronic small 
vessel ischemic disease.  The basal cisterns appear patent and 
there is 
preservation of gray-white matter differentiation.  
  
No fracture is identified.  Visualized paranasal sinuses, 
mastoid air cells, 
and middle ear cavities are clear.  The globes are intact.   
  
IMPRESSION:  Focus of hyperdensity in the cerebellum on the 
left, likely 
representing an intraparenchymal hemorrhage, less likely a 
hyperdense lesion 
such as a vascular malformation.  Recommend followup imaging to 
ensure 
expected evolution.

======================

===============

during her hospitalization and a PICC line was inserted.  She 
was planned for a treatment course  for a complicated UTI, for 
10 days (___).

finishing IV meropenem (last day ___.
